body.p: In a study, which of the following is the most important reason to use random allocation of subjects to the different treatments?

input.choice: To ensure that each subject in the trial receives the best possible treatment.
To guarantee that approximately the same number of subjects is assigned to each treatment group.
To protect the experimenters from legal action in the event that the experiment goes drastically awry.
To ensure that the different treatment groups are as similar as possible in every way except for the treatment received.
To guarantee that the results of the experiment can never be duplicated.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember that "treatments" in a study don’t necessarily refer to making the subjects "better," and random allocation wouldn’t ensure that anyway.
Incorrect. Although it’s true that random allocation would ensure roughly the same number of subjects per treatment group, that’s not the most important reason for the random allocation.

Incorrect. Random allocation in a study is important for a reason involving the interpretation of the results, not for legal protection; and random allocation wouldn’t ensure legal protection, anyway.

Correct. By ensuring that the treatment groups are as similar in every possible way except for the imposed treatment, random allocation eliminates lurking variablesand thus allows conclusions of causation.

Incorrect. Random allocation doesn’t prevent the experimental results from being replicated by other researchers. If it did, we wouldn’t do it, since replication is important to verify experimental results.

body.p: It is known that, in the United States, well-educated people are less likely to smoke. But what about other nations, where there may be different cultures and/or attitudes toward smoking? In a 1998 study of the relationship between education and smoking in France, a random sample of 334 French men was classified according to their education level (elementary, high-school, or university) and their smoking habits (smoker or nonsmoker).
Which of the following statements about this study is correct?

input.choice: This study is an experiment, since each subject was classified into one of the six possible combinations of education level and smoking habits.
This study is an experiment, since it was based on a random sample.
This study is an observational study, since researchers did not assign the men to be smokers or non-smokers, or to one of the education levels.
This study is a combination of both an experiment and an observational study.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Merely having subjects classified according to variables isn’t enough to make a study an experiment.
Incorrect. The sampling method isn’t what determines whether a study is an experiment.

Correct. A study is experimental if the researchers assigned the subjects to different values of the explanatory variable, and it’s observational otherwise. In this case, since subjects were only classified according to their own personally decided smoking habits, and since their education level also certainly wasn’t assigned by the researchers, this study was observational.
Incorrect. A study cannot be a mix of experiment and observation. A study is experimental if the researchers assigned the subjects to the explanatory variable, and it’s observational otherwise.

multiple_choice.body: In an experiment to see if aspirin reduces the chance of having a heart attack, which of the following would be a placebo?

input.choice: The place where the subjects go when they have a heart attack.
A dummy pill that looks like aspirin but has no active ingredients.
A procedure for deciding who gets the aspirin treatment.
The sampling method.
The randomization procedure.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The word placebo doesn’t refer to a place.

Correct. A placebo is a non-active treatment used in a study for proper comparison. In this case, it ensures that any comparative effect in the aspirin group is really due to the active ingredient rather than just due to the "placebo effect."
Incorrect. A placebo isn’t a procedure, and it doesn’t determine who gets the treatment.
Incorrect. A placebo isn’t a sampling method.
Incorrect. A placebo isn’t a procedure, and it doesn’t cause randomization.

body.p: Which of the following is the main advantage of experiments over observational studies?

input.choice: A well-designed experiment can give good evidence that the treatment actually causes the response.
An experiment can compare two or more groups.
An experiment is typically cheaper.
An experiment is typically shorter.
We can include more than one explanatory variable in an experiment.

response.feedback: Correct. An experiment is a study in which the treatments are assigned by the researchers. This allows the possibility of random assignment, which eliminates lurking variables and thus allows causation to be determined.
Incorrect. Observational studies can also compare groups. Merely having comparison of groups isn’t what makes something an experiment.
Incorrect. An experimental study is not necessarily cheaper than an observational study; and cost-savings wouldn’t be the most important benefit, anyway.
Incorrect. An experimental study is not necessarily shorter in duration than an observational study; and time-savings wouldn’t be the most important benefit, anyway.
Incorrect. Observational studies can also have more than one explanatory variable. The number of explanatory variables isn’t what makes something an experiment.

body.p: Students in a large statistics class were randomly divided into two groups. The first group took the midterm exam with soft music playing in the background, and the second group took the exam with no music playing. After the exam was completed, a researcher compared deidentified exam scores of the two groups.
Which of the following is the reason this experiment was not blind?

input.choice: The sample sizes in both groups was large.
Researchers looked at exam scores for the two groups.
The students knew whether or not music was playing while they were taking the exam.
Some of the students may not have studied for the exam.
Students were randomized into the two groups.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Blinding in study design has nothing to do with the size of the samples.
Incorrect. Since the researcher looked at scores without student names and conditions after the exam was complete, she was “blind” to which students were in each of the two conditions.

Correct. Blinding in study design is when the subjects don’t know which treatment they’re getting. In this case, the treatments are background music or no background music. The students would certainly be aware of whether music was playing during the exam, so they would know which treatment they got.
Incorrect. Blinding in study design does not refer to whether the students know the answers on the exam. It refers to whether the subjects are aware of something else pertaining to the study.
Incorrect. Having two randomized groups isn’t what determines whether or not a study is blind.

body.p: To test an herbal treatment for depression, 100 volunteers who suffered from mild depression were randomly divided into two groups. Each person was given a month's supply of tea bags. For one group, the tea contained the herb mixed with spice tea, whereas for the other group, the bags contained only the spice tea. Participants were not told which type of tea they had, and were asked to drink one cup of tea per day for a month. At the end of the month, a psychologist evaluated them to determine if their mood had improved. The psychologist did not know which of the subjects had the tea with the herbal ingredient added.
Which of the following statements is true regarding this study? Check all that apply.

input.choice: This study is an observational study.
This study is double-blind.
The "only spice tea" group serves as the control group.

response.feedback: Incorrect. A study is observational when the researcher doesn’t play any role in determining what treatment each subject might get. But in the study described, the researchers assigned each subject which tea to use, so the study wasn’t observational. Also, there is at least one true statement.

Incorrect. You are correct that the study is double-blind, because the subjects didn’t know which tea they got (which protects against the placebo effect), and the psychologist also didn’t know (which helps guard against researcher bias). However, there is at least one other true statement.
Incorrect. You are correct that the "only spice tea" group serves as the control group, because they didn’t get any active herbal ingredient. However, there is at least one other true statement.

Incorrect. body.p: For their 1992 study, "The Effect of Country Music on Suicide" (published in Social Forces, vol. 71, p. 211), researchers Stack and Gundlach investigated various American communities, recording the number of minutes of daily radio airtime devoted to country songs and the suicide rate. They found a moderately strong positive correlation.

In their paper, the researchers explain the results by saying that “…the themes found in country music foster a suicidal mood ...” (emphasis added). A news headline (The Independent [London], October 1, 2004, p. 15) about the research echoed these sentiments when it said, “Strange But True: Country Music Saps Will to Live.” The research is even cited on various suicide-prevention websites, some with headings such as “Country Music Increases Suicide Risk.”
Based on this study, can we have confidence in causality between country music and suicide?

input.choice: Yes, as long as the communities were sampled randomly, and the number of communities (the sample size) was sufficiently large.
Yes, causality is indicated by the moderately strong correlation.
Yes, since different communities listened to different levels of country music, meaningful experimental comparisons can be made.
No, because the lack of assignment of communities to different levels of country music listening means there is a possibility of lurking variables.
No, causality can only be demonstrated by investigating the entire population.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The sampling method only determines whether the relationship seen in the study can be generalized to the population (within the uncertainty of natural variability), but not whether the relationship demonstrates causation or merely association. The sample size only helps to determine the uncertainty due to natural variability, but not whether the relationship demonstrates causation.
Incorrect. The correlation only measures the strength of the relationship, but it doesn’t indicate whether the relationship demonstrates causation.
Incorrect. Only experiments can determine causation, but it’s not merely having comparisons that makes something an experiment. There can be comparisons in observational studies, too.

Correct. Causation can only be determined if the explanatory variable is randomly assigned. But in this case, the researchers didn’t randomly assign different amounts of country music to be played in different communities. So the study design doesn’t rule out lurking variables.
Incorrect. The entire population doesn’t need to be investigated to determine causation. A relationship can be determined to be causative based on the study design.
